sense.name: cause to undergo or be liable to
sense.examples: Answering the question may subject him to several penalties. They failed or neglected to subject him to reasonable parental control. The seven departments were subjected to internal audits. To do the study, they subjected cells to 25%, 50% and 75% deuterium oxide. They subjected themselves to the common fate of military men. They subjected fellow train passengers to a tirade of sectarian abuse. It will subject both new and existing loans to the higher reserve requirement.

sense.name: subjugate
sense.examples: In 1458 they subjected Greece, and took the Crimea soon afterwards. (1848)
